inventory.commentary: WordNet 2.1 sense 24 is not included here because it is vague, has no examples, and cannot be grouped into any of these senses with certainty

sense.name: move quickly or freely, travel
sense.examples: Don't run or you'll be out of breath! If you see this man, run! Who are these people running around here? She runs around telling everyone her troubles. Just let the dogs run. The children ran amok. She ran ten miles that day. He is running the marathon this year. I just need to run to the store. She ran to the arms of her lover. Savage ran the ball 19 times for 112 yards with a touchdown. The ship once again returned to sea to run the coast between New York and Savannah. Local salmon that run the waters of the Pacific are chinook and coho.

sense.name: extend over time/space or across a set
sense.examples: Service runs all the way to Cranbury. The highway from ignorance to knowledge runs both ways. Knowledge runs deep amongst the staff. Musical talent runs in the family. Run the wire behind the cabinet. The film runs five hours. Interest rates run from five to ten percent. Estimates for the losses in the earthquake run as high as two billion. These dresses run small.

sense.name: manage, enact, (cause to) operate
sense.examples: She is running a relief operation in the Sudan. They ran the tapes over and over again. Run the dishwasher. Our dishwaser is so quiet that I can't even hear it when it's running. The storyline runs like a stripped down Corvette, there aren't any frills, but it has a lot of balls. That idiot left the car running while he was inside. I can't run Windows on this machine. How do I run a process in the background? The purchasing power argument runs in a slightly different manner. You're the one that always runs the show. I just need to run a quick errand.

sense.name: guide, cause to move along a certain path
sense.examples: He ran his eyes over her body. She ran her fingers along the carved figurine. He ran his fingers through her hair.

sense.name: flow, as of liquids
sense.examples: This stretch of the Missouri runs slow and warm during the summer months. These dyes and colors are guaranteed not to run. He pours hot wax on all wicks, twirling them so that the wax runs evenly. My nose is running.

sense.name: present or perform (be presented); display (be displayed)
sense.examples: We ran the ad three times. The story ran for almost a month in the local paper. It's a good idea to run your plan by the program director. Show volunteers run through the show in front of members who critique the performance.

sense.name: campaign for a certain position
sense.examples: Who's running for treasurer this year? He announced today that he would run for president.

sense.name: be subject to, be affected by
sense.examples: Rest when you are tired or are running a fever. You run the danger of damaging your mental and physical health. They actually run a chance of slipping into hypoglycemia.

sense.name: keep company
sense.examples: He runs with a bad crowd. The heifers run with the bulls to produce offspring.

sense.name: trade illegally
sense.examples: Grandma ran drugs to support her bingo habit. Running moonshine on the back roads was not a job for the fainthearted.

sense.name: cause animals to move
sense.commentary: used of animals in specific domains includes forcing animals to run in a certain path (as of sled dogs, or racehorses) allowing animals to roam free to graze; also includes dogs running wild animals being hunted
sense.examples: The handlers ran their dogs around the track. The dogs ran the deer, and the hunters shot them. It's not because he's a cheater, it's because he runs horses where they can win. I run cattle on rolling hills with very little standing water. The Fairbanks area in one of the best places in the world to run sled dogs.

sense.name: unravel
sense.examples: I can see heels and pearls flying, hear dresses ripping, nylons running! If snagging happens, simply snip off the loop and the snag won't run.

sense.name: move quickly, run in a particular direction
sense.examples: The kids ran around all day. Did your dog just run by? I said hello, and he ran off. She ran out of the room crying.

sense.name: flee, escape control
sense.examples: Did you ever run away from home when you were a kid? Inflation is running away. Mark ran off with his brother's stamp collection. She ran off with Steve to get married.

sense.name: flow (in a certain direction or with a certain result)
sense.commentary: Includes: RUN DOWN; RUN OFF; RUN OUT; RUN OVER
sense.examples: Water ran down the outside of the glass. The sewage ran off into the river. Gasoline ran out of the leaky tank bit by bit. The bathtub ran over.

sense.name: (cause to) become empty or exhusted of something
sense.commentary: Includes: RUN DOWN; RUN DRY; RUN LOW; RUN OUT; RUN SHORT; RUN THROUGH
sense.examples: I ran myself down during exam week. They ran down their savings when they renovated their kitchen. The keg ran dry half-way through the party. We're running low on sugar. She seemed to run out of energy near the end of the race. My passport ran out last month. The rice stores ran out before the next crop came in. I am running short of patience! They ran through their office supplies by June.

sense.name: meet, encounter
sense.examples: She ran across some old college friends. I ran into Sam yesterday at the hardware store. They ran into several problems with the software.

sense.name: injure or kill by traveling over
sense.examples: George was run down by a Toyota last night. I accidentally ran over a squirrel.

sense.name: extend or continue for a certain amount of time
sense.examples: The movie ran for three hours. That meeting ran on for half the day. Boy, can he run on!

sense.name: RUN AFOUL--go against, conflict with
sense.examples: He ran afoul of the law.

sense.name: RUN AGROUND--(cause to) come to the ground
sense.examples: The storm ran the ship aground.

sense.name: RUN ALONG--be in line with
sense.examples: Oaks run all along the drive.

sense.name: pursue until caught or found
sense.examples: The sheriff ran down the suspect in the mall parking lot. I ran down those figures you wanted.

sense.name: scan
sense.examples: She ran down the list, looking for his name.

sense.name: collide
sense.examples: My son ran into a bench his first day with a driver's license.

sense.name: drive out
sense.examples: He ran off the trespassers with his shotgun.

sense.name: photocopy
sense.examples: Will you run off 50 copies of this brochure?

sense.name: decide by a runoff
sense.examples: We'll run off ten finalists to determine the winner.

sense.name: RUN UP--accumulate, increase
sense.examples: They ran up the score on their rivals. He ran up considerable debt gambling.

sense.name: RUN UP--hoist
sense.examples: The pirates ran up the Jolly Roger, a flag that struck fear into the hearts of many sailors.

sense.name: RUN UP--sew
sense.examples: I can run up a skirt for you in no time.

sense.name: multiword expressions
sense.commentary: RUN A RISK: gamble, put at risk RUN BASES: baseball term, run around the bases RUN ROUGHSHOD: treat inconsiderately or roughly
sense.examples: He's running a risk by letting you in after hours. He ran the bases and tied the score. My mother-in-law runs roughshod over my feelings.
